links.slidetitle: Thank you for viewing my work.
links.displaytext: Thank you for viewing my work.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.Text:
In this course, we will discuss the challenges that come with conversations that may make some people uncomfortable. A difficult conversation is a conversation where you must manage emotions and information in a sensitive way in order to:

Address performance or conduct.

Deal with personal problems.

Investigate complaints or deal with grievances.

Comfort or reassure an employee. For example during a lay-off .

And tackle personality clashes.

Everyone has their own preferences, personal biases, culture and world views. Cultivating an appreciation of differences in others is an important factor in ensuring that conversations are thoughtful. For every interaction, there is an opportunity for misunderstanding. When we are dealing with a difficult conversation, the more self awareness we have, the more likely it is we will have a positive interaction. Let’s learn about some tools to aid in this awareness.

If you have a difficult conversation ahead of you, one of the worst things you can do is to put it off, or postpone it until the “perfect time”. Depending on the topic, depending on the topic, provide the employee with advanced notice regarding what you want to talk about. Then, schedule a time to talk about it. Next, let’s look at ways to anticipate the conversation at hand, and plan ahead.

It might seem counterintuitive to plan a conversation ahead of time. But in the case of a difficult conversation. planning can help make the conversation easier. Let’s learn how planning can be beneficial.

Before you speak with an employee, spend time thinking about the following:

Identify what is important.

What are the talking points. And finally, what has worked in the past.

Click the Sticky Notes to learn more.

The following example, illustrates a difficult conversation that escalates with each comment. As you follow this example, consider the opportunities that each person had to ensure better communication. As this course. progresses, keep this conversation in mind as strategies are outlined to avoid or deal with this type of escalation.

‘I statements’ are often used with the intention of asserting how the person who is saying the statement feels, without putting blame on another person for their feelings. ‘I statements’ are used to take ownership of one’s feelings. This type of statement is especially helpful during a difficult conversation in the event that the conversation becomes personal. Let’s look at how these statements are constructed.
Reframing is seeing the current situation from a different perspective. It can be tremendously helpful in problem solving and in managing difficult conversations. Let’s listen to an example.

Validation is similar to reframing. There’s a slight difference in how the information is presented. In this example, the manager is validating the employees feelings to demonstrate empathy and understanding. Listen to the example, can you spot the difference?

You are not impartial. You favor Lisa’s work over mine.

Is there any truth to this statement? When you disagree with an employee, remain constructive. Outline your reasons for disagreement. If a statement has caught you off guard, and you have no idea how respond, or if you feel angry about the statement, then be honest with the employee. Inform them that you need time to consider what they have said. Agree to get back with them when you’ve had an opportunity to collect your thoughts. Remember, use ‘I statements’ to take ownership of any feelings you express.
